context: Families and households were still largely independent economically, and <a0_0>the household<a0_0/> was probably the center of life. However, <b7_0>excavations in Central Europe<b7_0/> have revealed that early Neolithic Linear Ceramic cultures ("Linearbandkeramik") were building large arrangements of circular ditches between <a1_0><b4_0>4800 BC and 4600 BC<b4_0/><a1_0/>. These structures (and their later counterparts such as <a2_0><b5_0>causewayed enclosures, burial mounds, and henge<b5_0/><a2_0/>) <a3_0><b6_0>required considerable time and labour to construct<b6_0/><a3_0/>, which suggests <b8_0>that some influential individuals were able to organise and direct human labour<b8_0/> — though non-hierarchical and voluntary work remain possibilities.
